text: I love Webflow. We're using a template, and I've been adding and iterating on top of that. I love the control Webflow gives me to move things around and customize small details, while still being very clean and intuitive to use. We'll see how things go once we launch the site and need to add new stuff via the CMS, but so far I'm sold.

text:
There are different ways to go about it. If you don't want to get the quick wins first, you could work your way from the oldest to the newest. I'd suggest doing that by category so it's easier to see which posts can be merged if needed.

If you have posts that are in any way timely, I would map those out on a calendar and update them about 2-3 months before they become relevant again. Examples are posts around specific holidays, sales periods, annual events, etc.

In terms of metrics, I look at traffic evolution (has traffic to this post been steadily declining?) as well as how much traffic a post gets overall. It might have never done well to start with and then it doesn't really matter if traffic has gone down or not.

I also check keyword rankings and whether the main keyword an article is targeting is the best possible one for that article in terms of traffic potential and search intent fit.

And then you also just want to make sure that your content is factually correct and up-to-date regardless of all of the SEO stuff.

Hope that helps!

elements.text:
There are different ways to go about it. If you don't want to get the quick wins first, you could work your way from the oldest to the newest. I'd suggest doing that by category so it's easier to see which posts can be merged if needed.

If you have posts that are in any way timely, I would map those out on a calendar and update them about 2-3 months before they become relevant again. Examples are posts around specific holidays, sales periods, annual events, etc.

In terms of metrics, I look at traffic evolution (has traffic to this post been steadily declining?) as well as how much traffic a post gets overall. It might have never done well to start with and then it doesn't really matter if traffic has gone down or not.

I also check keyword rankings and whether the main keyword an article is targeting is the best possible one for that article in terms of traffic potential and search intent fit.

And then you also just want to make sure that your content is factually correct and up-to-date regardless of all of the SEO stuff.

Hope that helps!

text: Here's how I think about it:

elements.text: Here's how I think about it:

text: 1. <@U01MM4EAC69> this is such a poignant question/issue but I'm with you. For social to 'work', resources _*need to*_ be invested to enable constant reiteration and experimentation. Social media is a lead generator for a few of our B2B clients and that's largely in part to:   1) Dividing the audience into investors/partners/customers/ prospect segments and then creating different types of multimedia/messaging with varying tones to pull each segment in.                                                      2) Using Google Analytics and Data Studio while tagging as much asset interactions as we can to see where social engagement participates in the funnel. For e.g. if you put a new eBook out, the funnel may look like this: Social channels>Blog>Landing page>Asset download (and a few other variations). We look to see how much of our social campaigns are pushing prospects through and where the traffic has sharp declines or growth.                                                        We also spend a good amount of time every month, actually looking at new follower samples and asking "are the people we're attracting part of the brand's ICP?" (that helps in calculating the success of tactics baked out to support point 1).  All of this to say: Social can definitely work for demand gen (especially if you tie GA performance to your CRM) but it's not as straightforward as New followers = New Business.

For e.g. if you put a new eBook out, the funnel may look like this: Social channels>Blog>Landing page>Asset download (and a few other variations). We look to see how much of our social campaigns are pushing prospects through and where the traffic has sharp declines or growth.                                                        We also spend a good amount of time every month, actually looking at new follower samples and asking "are the people we're attracting part of the brand's ICP?" (that helps in calculating the success of tactics baked out to support point 1).  All of this to say: Social can definitely work for demand gen (especially if you tie GA performance to your CRM) but it's not as straightforward as New followers = New Business.

text:
<https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/historical-blog-seo-conversion-optimization|HubSpot> has a great framework for updating blog content based on 2 main buckets!

1. which posts are performing well in terms of traffic, but are low converting — opportunity to update for conversions
2. which posts are performing well in terms of conversions but have low traffic — opportunity for SEO optimization 
separately for all content, I think about programs and campaigns we’re running and which are resonating the most (lots of webinar reg, engagement in the chat, etc.) and use that as a way to prioritize updating related content with new information

which posts are performing well in terms of traffic, but are low converting — opportunity to update for conversions

separately for all content, I think about programs and campaigns we’re running and which are resonating the most (lots of webinar reg, engagement in the chat, etc.) and use that as a way to prioritize updating related content with new information

text: I am working on a site that has a bunch of urls for their podcast with an embedded player and transcripts. We are concerned that having this many pages (hundreds of urls) that aren't getting clicks might be hurting SEO. Would it be better to move those pages to a subdomain or a new URL? what has been your experience with this and do you know of a good solution?

elements.text: I am working on a site that has a bunch of urls for their podcast with an embedded player and transcripts. We are concerned that having this many pages (hundreds of urls) that aren't getting clicks might be hurting SEO. Would it be better to move those pages to a subdomain or a new URL? what has been your experience with this and do you know of a good solution?

text: You might want to try subdomains instead of new URLs

elements.text: You might want to try subdomains instead of new URLs

text: Bc the current URLs have domain authority, it's much easier to use subdomains + index and having Google recrawl

elements.text: Bc the current URLs have domain authority, it's much easier to use subdomains + index and having Google recrawl

text: thanks <@U0353AN9487>, so better to put on a subdomain like <http://podcast.maindomain.com|podcast.maindomain.com> and then just redirect all the old urls to new ones?

elements.text: thanks
, so better to put on a subdomain like
podcast.maindomain.com
and then just redirect all the old urls to new ones?

text: Hmm, you should just be able to index, so maindomain/podcast/podcast title... I'm not sure that would need 303 redirects but I could be wrong!

elements.text: Hmm, you should just be able to index, so maindomain/podcast/podcast title... I'm not sure that would need 303 redirects but I could be wrong!

text: If they're on topic with the main topic of the site, they aren't hurting you. You'd need thousands and thousands of low quality pages to see it worth an effort like this.

elements.text: If they're on topic with the main topic of the site, they aren't hurting you. You'd need thousands and thousands of low quality pages to see it worth an effort like this.

text: We had a similar problem and ended up consolidating them into one big page instead of lots of little ones

elements.text: We had a similar problem and ended up consolidating them into one big page instead of lots of little ones

text:
I'm curious to know: *What are your biggest FAQs or sources of confusion about content strategy?*

I'll go first :slightly_smiling_face: A question I'm ALWAYS asking myself is "how can I make sure this strategy is actionable and usable?" I'm an independent consultant and I've seen so many companies work so hard to set a strategy and then it collects dust in a Google Drive folder somewhere as they go and chase shiny objects lol.
